frames.text: receptor signaling pathways lead to T reg differentiation
frames.verbose-text: Repertoire studies suggest that distinct T cell receptor signaling pathways lead to T reg differentiation, but the signals that regulate T reg specification are largely unknown.

frames.text: AKT substantially diminished TGF-β–induced Foxp3 expression
frames.verbose-text: A constitutively active allele of AKT substantially diminished TGF-β–induced Foxp3 expression in a kinase-dependent manner and via a rapamycin-sensitive pathway, implicating the AKT–mammalian target of rapamycin axis.

A constitutively active allele of AKT substantially diminished TGF-β–induced Foxp3 expression in a kinase-dependent manner and via a rapamycin-sensitive pathway, implicating the AKT–mammalian target of rapamycin axis.

A constitutively active allele of AKT substantially diminished TGF-β–induced Foxp3 expression in a kinase-dependent manner and via a rapamycin-sensitive pathway, implicating the AKT–mammalian target of rapamycin axis.

frames.text: AKT at a stage before Foxp3 turn on during normal T reg differentiation in the thymus selectively impaired differentiation
frames.verbose-text: Expression of active AKT at a stage before Foxp3 turn on during normal T reg differentiation in the thymus selectively impaired differentiation of CD4+Foxp3+ cells without any alteration in the positive selection of Tconv.

frames.text: AKT at a stage before Foxp3 turn on during normal T reg differentiation in the thymus selectively impaired differentiation of CD4+
frames.verbose-text: Expression of active AKT at a stage before Foxp3 turn on during normal T reg differentiation in the thymus selectively impaired differentiation of CD4+Foxp3+ cells without any alteration in the positive selection of Tconv.

Expression of active AKT at a stage before Foxp3 turn on during normal T reg differentiation in the thymus selectively impaired differentiation of CD4+Foxp3+ cells without any alteration in the positive selection of Tconv.
Activated AKT, in contrast, did not affect established Foxp3 expression in T reg cells.
Furthermore, ectopic expression of Foxp3 is sufficient, in certain experimental settings, to impart suppressive function to conventional CD4+ (Tconv) cells (5).
In addition, in vitro activation of peripheral CD4+CD25− T cells in the presence of TGF-β and IL-2 induces Foxp3 expression and conversion to T reg cells in various model systems (10, 11).
In addition, in vitro activation of peripheral CD4+CD25− T cells in the presence of TGF-β and IL-2 induces Foxp3 expression and conversion to T reg cells in various model systems (10, 11).

frames.text: TGF-β and IL-2 induces Foxp3 expression
frames.verbose-text: In addition, in vitro activation of peripheral CD4+CD25− T cells in the presence of TGF-β and IL-2 induces Foxp3 expression and conversion to T reg cells in various model systems (10, 11).

Despite an extensive literature on the function of T reg cells in a variety of contexts, little is known about the signaling mechanisms involved in their differentiation and maintenance, or in the regulation of Foxp3 expression.
Most notably, the activation of the phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K)–AKT pathway, as indicated by a reduction in AKT phosphorylation, was impaired in T reg cells.
In this paper, we address the functional consequence of deregulated AKT activity on T reg differentiation and Foxp3 expression.

Our results describe a unique and surprising effect of AKT in negatively regulating the induction of a broad swath of the T reg transcriptional signature, thereby identifying a signaling component that selectively affects T reg lineage differentiation.RESULTSAKT* impairs de novo Foxp3 induction by TGF-βTo explore the functional relevance of a hyperactivated PI3K–AKT pathway on T reg cell generation and maintenance, we first used an in vitro system wherein the activation of CD4+CD25− cells in the presence of TGF-β and IL-2 induces de novo expression of Foxp3 (10).

frames.text: CD25− cells in the presence of TGF-β and IL-2 induces de novo expression of Foxp3

Retrovirus-mediated expression of AKT* significantly impaired the induction of Foxp3 by TGF-β (Fig. 1 A; a summary of several independent experiments is shown in Fig. 1 B).
Retrovirus-mediated expression of AKT* significantly impaired the induction of Foxp3 by TGF-β (Fig. 1 A; a summary of several independent experiments is shown in Fig. 1 B).

frames.text: AKT* significantly impaired the induction of Foxp3
frames.verbose-text: Retrovirus-mediated expression of AKT* significantly impaired the induction of Foxp3 by TGF-β (Fig. 1 A; a summary of several independent experiments is shown in Fig. 1 B).
The diminished expression of Foxp3 at the protein level was paralleled at the mRNA level, pointing to an effect on mRNA transcription or stability (Fig. 1 C).

frames.text: AKT* vector did promote cell survival
frames.verbose-text: As expected, our AKT* vector did promote cell survival in conditions of cytokine deprivation (Fig. S1, available at http://www.jem.org/cgi/content/full/jem.20071477/DC1).

The ability of AKT* to block Foxp3 induction was dependent on its kinase activity; a mutant AKT that shares the myristoylated modification found in AKT* but carries an inactivating mutation of the kinase domain (KD-AKT(K179M)) (37) was unable to affect TGF-β–mediated Foxp3 induction (Fig. 1 E).

The ability of AKT* to block Foxp3 induction was dependent on its kinase activity; a mutant AKT that shares the myristoylated modification found in AKT* but carries an inactivating mutation of the kinase domain (KD-AKT(K179M)) (37) was unable to affect TGF-β–mediated Foxp3 induction (Fig. 1 E).

frames.text: expression of the antiapoptotic molecule Bcl-2 or the protooncogene c-Myc
frames.verbose-text: This effect of AKT* was specific, in that no significant difference in Foxp3 induction was observed upon expression of the antiapoptotic molecule Bcl-2 or the protooncogene c-Myc, which, as with AKT, have been implicated in T cell survival (Fig. 1 F).

Expression of Foxp3 was determined after a total of 4 d of culture.
The reduction in the number of Foxp3+ cells was less severe at later time points, although AKT* could still reduce the intensity of Foxp3 expression in positive cells (Fig. 2 A, bottom).
The continuous presence of TGF-β is necessary to maintain Foxp3 expression in such cultures; i.e., Foxp3 begins to disappear within 24 h of TGF-β withdrawal (unpublished data) (38).
AKT* seems to affect this continued “confirmation” of Foxp3 expression as well as the initial induction.Differential effect of AKT on established levels of Foxp3.

Contrary to what we had observed for the TGF-β–induced Foxp3 in Tconv cells, the Foxp3 levels in the natural T reg cell cultures were refractory to downmodulation upon retroviral expression of AKT* (Fig. 2 B).

Contrary to what we had observed for the TGF-β–induced Foxp3 in Tconv cells, the Foxp3 levels in the natural T reg cell cultures were refractory to downmodulation upon retroviral expression of AKT* (Fig. 2 B).

Although transduced T reg cells did tend to express slightly lower levels of AKT* overall (as suggested by the bicistronic Thy1.1 reporter), this resistance was not caused by a lower level of AKT* because the resistance was observed at AKT*/Thy1.1 levels that elicited complete inhibition in TGF-β–treated naive cells (Fig. 2 B).

frames.text: down-regulated by AKT*, respectively, far more than in the randomized CTRL
frames.verbose-text: The Multiplot module from GenePattern (39) was used for data visualization.Overall, the introduction of AKT* led to a substantial number of changes in the overall profile of TCR/IL-2/TGF-β–activated cells: at an arbitrary fold change threshold of 1.5, 610 and 1,381 probes were up- and down-regulated by AKT*, respectively, far more than in the randomized CTRL dataset (Fig. 3 A).

frames.text: AKT* did not elicit a wholesale block of TGF-β
frames.verbose-text: Thus, AKT* did not elicit a wholesale block of TGF-β signaling nor did it solely shut down Foxp3, but rather, it targeted a specific subset of genes, one of which was Foxp3.AKT* specifically targets a subset of the TGF-β signature.
Regions R1 and R3 highlight TGF-β–regulated genes that are refractory to AKT* expression.
This distribution argued against a model in which the observed downmodulation of R2 genes by AKT* was simply the result of a shutdown of Foxp3 expression.

frames.text: Foxp3 levels in AKT*-transduced cells were restored by coinfection
frames.verbose-text: For an independent confirmation of this result, we performed dual-transduction experiments in which Foxp3 levels in AKT*-transduced cells were restored by coinfection with a retroviral vector encoding FoxP3 (Fig. 5 B).

For an independent confirmation of this result, we performed dual-transduction experiments in which Foxp3 levels in AKT*-transduced cells were restored by coinfection with a retroviral vector encoding FoxP3 (Fig. 5 B).

frames.text: Foxp3 restored the levels of Foxp3
frames.verbose-text: The forced expression of exogenous Foxp3 restored the levels of Foxp3 transcripts comparable to those of uninfected cells (Fig. 5 C).

frames.text: Foxp3 did not restore the expression levels of Ctla4
frames.verbose-text: However, restoration of Foxp3 did not restore the expression levels of Ctla4 or Gpr83 transcripts (Fig. 5 C), validating the conclusion that AKT* affected transcripts of the T reg signature independent of its effect on Foxp3.Impact of AKT* on Foxp3-dependent and -independent genes.

Data represent the mean ± SEM.Effect of AKT on de novo generation of Foxp3+CD4+ thymocytesT reg cells are viewed as a distinct lineage that arises in the thymus and depends on interactions between the TCR and MHC–peptide complexes (20).
Foxp3 expression can be observed as early as the CD4+CD8+ double-positive (DP) stage of thymocyte differentiation; T reg cells accumulate as maturing cells (41, 42).
By itself, rapamycin did not affect TGF-β–mediated induction of Foxp3 (Fig. 7).
However, rapamycin treatment of cells at the time of AKT* transduction did counteract the inhibitory effect of AKT*, although it did not completely restore Foxp3 levels to those of uninhibited cells.

On the other hand, because the impact of AKT* was not completely abolished by rapamycin, additional rapamycin-insensitive pathways may also be involved.Molecular mechanisms of AKT-mediated suppression of Foxp3 induction.
Foxp3 expression was determined by flow cytometry.
The ability of AKT to inhibit Foxp3 expression was limited to the induction phase of Foxp3 both in vivo and in vitro.
The ability of AKT to inhibit Foxp3 expression was limited to the induction phase of Foxp3 both in vivo and in vitro.
Natural T reg cells with established and stable Foxp3 levels were resistant to AKT*'s effect.

frames.text: demethylation of CpG motifs and histone
frames.verbose-text: Support for this notion was recently provided by Floess et al., who noted complete demethylation of CpG motifs and histone modifications within the Foxp3 locus in natural T reg cells but not after TGF-β induction (47).

These findings argue for a level of similarity for these two populations and place AKT at a nexus of signaling pathways whose proper activation has a considerable impact on Foxp3 expression and, consequently, T reg cell generation.

Indeed, given the involvement of AKT as a positive regulator in CD28 and IL-2R signaling (55), both of which are important for Foxp3 expression, our findings may appear somewhat paradoxical.Activation of AKT is lower in T reg than in Tconv cells after TCR (32) and IL-2R (33) engagement.

Our study suggests that this impairment may not merely be a consequence of defective signaling, but that it may serve as an active safeguard mechanism to ensure sufficient levels of Foxp3 and other elements of the T reg signature required for T reg differentiation and for the suppressive functions of T reg cells.

frames.text: AKT might override these functions and ultimately contribute to immune disease
frames.verbose-text: An overly active AKT might override these functions and ultimately contribute to immune disease.

Indeed, mice expressing AKT* present with autoimmune manifestations such as multiorgan lymphocytic infiltration and autoantibodies (34, 35), although no obvious phenotype in CD4+CD25+ T cells has been observed in such mice (56).
Our study provides additional potential explanations for this phenotype, whereby deregulated expression of AKT alters the thymic and perhaps peripheral generation of T reg cells.
An alternative implication may relate to recent data that show that Foxp3 induction by TGF-β can be blocked by proinflammatory cytokines such as IL-6, leading to generation of Th17 cells (58).

Moreover, these findings suggest that small molecules that target AKT might prove efficacious in treatment of autoimmunity and inflammation by targeting both overreacting effector T cells as well as enhancing T reg cell generation.The repression of Foxp3 expression by AKT* required its kinase activity and was partly counteracted by rapamycin treatment, adding a potential element to its mechanism of action and placing mTOR as a downstream target of AKT.

Moreover, these findings suggest that small molecules that target AKT might prove efficacious in treatment of autoimmunity and inflammation by targeting both overreacting effector T cells as well as enhancing T reg cell generation.The repression of Foxp3 expression by AKT* required its kinase activity and was partly counteracted by rapamycin treatment, adding a potential element to its mechanism of action and placing mTOR as a downstream target of AKT.

frames.text: rapamycin treatment may also contribute to the generation of new T reg cells by counteracting molecular brakes on Foxp3 induction.MATERIALS AND METHODSMice.NOD/LtDOI, BDC2.5/NOD TCR
frames.verbose-text: In addition to selectively preserving and expanding existing T reg populations, rapamycin treatment may also contribute to the generation of new T reg cells by counteracting molecular brakes on Foxp3 induction.MATERIALS AND METHODSMice.NOD/LtDOI, BDC2.5/NOD TCR transgenic, C57BL/6, and B6.SJL-Ptprca Pep3b/BoyJ (CD45.1+) mice were bred in the mouse specific pathogen-free animal facility at the Joslin Diabetes Center or were purchased from the Jackson Laboratory.
